title: How important do you think the contribution of ancient Greeks in philosophy is? - Quora

response.answer_text: Incalculably so. Just for starters they invented the idea of philosophy itself. So some might say without them it wouldn’t exist as it does today, being led by Eastern thought instead. They pursued natural philosophy, the precursor to science, like Thales of Miletus or Aristotle, and more abstract ideals like Plato. They pioneered new ways to talk about knowledge and argue, like Socrates. Aristotle is responsible for creating a system of formal logic that we still largely use today. He also mused on the fundamentals of political philosophy along with Plato, examining themes of Justice, Virtue, who the best rulers were, what man’s place in the natural world was. Because these early thinkers covered such fundamental questions, they remain relevant to modern readers. As an example, Plato’s dissection of justice in the Republic will either be refreshingly thorough or laboriously long. Even if you disagree with his conclusions, it’s still valuable to remind oneself of what it is we criticise or champion in an age where we assume we know so well what justice is that we either take it’s importance for granted or dismiss its value in a relativistic world. People like Pythagoras and Euclid turned mathematics into its own field of study. Nearly every one had their own theories on the nature of reality. Thales thought everything was made up of water in various forms. Democritus thought it was made up of tiny invisible pieces called atoms (though not quite how we know them, the fundamental notion of them was in place). It’s questions and thoughts like these that got people to investigate realms they previously hadn’t thought existed. Why look beyond the human senses if you don’t think they are limited? When Medieval Europe rediscovered Aristotle’s works around the 12th century, he formed the basis of Christian natural theology for centuries. So in the most literal sense the legacy of Ancient Greek philosophy influenced the core of the world’s most widespread set of ideals which would come to spread to the four corners of the earth. In an increasingly secular Europe, the fact that, in many people’s lives, the Greek philosophers would outlive Christianity despite being half a millennium older than it, says something about how ingrained in the Western mind they are.
